marc:datafield.marc:subfield: William Hay was a resident of Franklin County, Georgia.
Deeds and surveyor's plat of several tracts of land sold by William Hay.
Benjamin Hawkins was an Indian agent for all tribes South of the Ohio River at the time this letter was written.
Letter from Hawkins requesting powder and lead from the United States factor, Edward Price.
Jonathan Harvey was a merchant in Baltimore, Maryland.
Contains Harvey's business correspondence with a Philadelphia bank and a New York mercantile house.
Francis Lister Hawks was a lawyer, Protestant Episcopal minister, editor, and historian, and a resident of New Bern, North Carolina. His father, Francis Hawks, was collector of the port of New Bern.
Letter of Francis L. Hawks concerning the printing of his work on the North Carolina Supreme Court and the other from Hawk's father describing a suspicious vessel in 1810.
John A. Haven was a [merchant?], of Boston, Massachusetts.
Business letters to W.F. and B. Salter, merchants in Fayetteville, N.C., concerning Boston prices.
Philo Hatch was a resident of Barrington, Yates County., New York.
Deeds between Hatch and Joseph Barthalomew.
Thomas D. Hathaway was a resident of Edenton, North Carolina.
Letter of T.A. Jordan, of Gatesville, North Carolina, concerning the reception given Baptist ministers in that town.
Peter W. Hawthorne was a resident of Lunenburg County, Virginia.
Letters from Hawthorne's sister and from a business associate, Nathaniel Reise.
Byron M. Hawks was a lawyer and teacher, of Monroe County, New York.

Letters concerning Hawks' student life at Dartmouth, 1846-1848; teaching in an academy at South Yarmouth, Massachusetts, 1848; problems of establishing a law practice on the frontier in Fond du Lac (Wisconsin or Minnesota) and personal and family matters. Most of the collection is made up of checks and bills relating to Rochester, New York.
Susan L. Hathorn was the wife of Jode Hathorn, captain of the barque, J.J. HATHORN. She was the ship's bookkeeper, read the chronometer, and recorded the time, latitude, and longitude.

Collection consists of a volume that has 105 pages of diary entries and 16 pages of financial accounts. The diary begins when the ship is in Cuba after starting it's journey in Philadelphia. Hathorn records more information about her domestic life than about her husband, but she presents a clear and detailed description of what daily life was like for the wife of a commercial sailing captain. She also describes how the ship was left in Savannah, Georgia, when she and her husband visited friends in Maine. She remained with her family when the ship was sold and gave birth to a daughter. The remainder of the volume contains a list of expenses.
John W. Haskins was a resident of Buckingham County, Virginia.
Personal correspondence of the Haskins family, with brief references to agricultural and educational conditions immediately after the Civil War.
Marmaduke J. Hawkins was a lawyer and local politician of Ridgeway (Warren County), North Carolina.
Business and political correspondence. Among the correspondents are Walter Clark and F.M. Simmons.
John Hawkins was a resident of Ithaca, Tompkins County, New York.
Business correspondence to Hawkins, discussing prices of corn, oats, and horses.
William Clifton Harvey was a Confederate soldier in the 43rd Virginia Infantry Regiment, from Petersburg (Dinwiddie County), Virginia.
A letter, memorandum book, copybook, and two diaries relating to his military service.
Eliza Hastings was a resident of North Carolina.
Personal letters of Eliza, James A., and Thomas W. Hastings, including a few Confederate soldier's letters.

The Hasler family were residents of New York, New York; there were three sons. John Hasler was a member of the Light Battery E, 1st Pennsylvania Artillery in the Union army. George was in Company H of the 13th New York Infantry Volunteers.

Collection contains letters from brothers John, William, and George Hasler, to their parents, while stationed in various camps in Pennsylvania, Virginia, Maryland, and Tennessee. John writes of an expected battle in Richmond, and of the Petersburg campaign. Letter topics include family and money, health, camp life, weather, troop movements, and military pay.
Elijah T. D. Hawkins was a Confederate soldier in the 46th Georgia Volunteers.

Letters from Elijah Hawkins to his family. One letter, July 23, 1864, mentions a Confederate victory in the Atlanta campaign the day previous, in which General William H.T. Walker was killed and General States Rights Gist and Tillman Hawkins, Elijah's brother, were wounded.
William E. Hawks was a resident of New York, New York.
Bills of Hawks and of William E. Hawks, Jr., officers of the Soda Springs Land and Cattle Company.
Soda Springs Land and Cattle Company.
Stephen F. Hathaway was a soldier with Company C, 14th Regiment, Massachusetts Volunteers and 36th United States Colored Troops.

Letters written by Stephen Hathaway to his cousin Gus in Boston. Many of the Civil War letters were written from Fort Duncan, Maryland. Among the topics mentioned are Hooker's army; military activities leading up to the Battle of Gettysburg; Grant's movements; prisoners; Confederate deserters; Confederate fear of Sherman; the death of Abraham Lincoln; and the fate of Jefferson Davis. After the Civil War, Hathaway wrote from Brazos Santiago, Texas, while stationed there with the 36th U.S. Colored Troops, and expressed his enjoyment of the area.
William J. Harwood was a resident of Richmond, Virginia.
Copy of an agreement with W. B. Rose concerning transfer of land in Henrico County, Virginia.
A letter from John Jay thanking Hayden for corrections to a speech Jay had delivered.

John Hay was an American statesman, diplomat, author, journalist, and private secretary and assistant to Abraham Lincoln. Hay's highest office was serving as United States Secretary of State under Presidents William McKinley and Theodore Roosevelt.
Note by Hay acknowledging a letter from B.F. Brown.
